fields.headline: Breathless
fields.bodyText: Brace yourselves. Yang Ik-Joon's Breathless is a horribly nasty and violent drama from South Korea whose purpose is to show – probably entirely accurately – that the psychological origins of organised gang violence lie in family dysfunction. Only those who come from abusive families can be reliably and professionally violent. Yang Ik-Joon directs and stars as Song-hoon, the ugly and ferocious mob debt collector for whom violence is a way of effacing memories of how he failed to stand up to a violent father. He swears compulsively and has the classic gangster habit of perpetually slapping people around the head: a kind of abusive tic that he probably doesn't even recognise as particularly violent. His life changes when he meets a defiant high-school girl from the same abusive background as him: her brother yearns to join Song-hoon's mob. The pre-credit sequence, in which Song-hoon beats up a total stranger for beating up his girlfriend in the street, and then beats up the girlfriend, gives us the film in essence: it functions as a brutal short film in itself, after which the rest of the feature is a little superfluous. I wondered what the point was, after a while.
